html: 4.14.22  3:04 pm   I have a theory that the vast majority of people are terrible at understanding other people. In fact, I'm convinced that they don't even understand themselves. They may think they do, but they really don't. Do you agree with this theory?
4.14.22  1:17 pm   what key is the next song in?

4.14.22  12:59 pm   Writing music has always been difficult for me, but I want to do it more than most things. I have made tons of attempted songs, and there are people who say that they enjoy listening to them, but I still personally struggle with the idea that nothing I make is good. The little details like the tone of my voice, uneven piano playing, and overall quality issues suppress my music making constantly. People say that I shouldn't worry about it and that I am a perfectionist, but I don't feel like I can release or share anything I make the the world without knowing personally that it is of a proper level of quality, and none of the songs I have made have reached that insurmountable goal I've set myself. My question is, what should I do? Is there something else I can try to improve my opinion of my music, or should I just keep trying to make something that I think is good, and that I know I will never make.

4.14.22  11:56 am   i have been thinking about,and using, your advice and practice, of coming up with your words while singing to them. it really was helpful, and it made me realize that every singer has different capabilities of singing different types of syllabbles musically, and for it all to make sense you need to remember what comes most comfortable to you. and the only way to remember that is to sing? at first maybe, this might be improvable... i wanted to share my thoughts about that, and also, to ask you some questions about the topic. do you feel like there are specific lyrical vocal-zones for you that makes it hard to sing?

     and also, are you comfortable with singing a song in a language that you don't know?

      when you do it, do you try to understand the lyrics first?

4.12.22  7:00 pm   recently almost every chorus/prechorus idea i've been excited about has had a 4 chord under the first bar of it. |4|1|5|6m 5|, |4|6m|5|2m 1|, |4|5|3m|6m|, |4|5|6m|1|, |4|6m|3m|3m|, etc. (i come up with the melody before or at the same time as the chords, so i'm not doing anything chords-first.) i think what appeals to me is that it feels like you're near the base of a mountain, looking up at the top of the mountain. it gives you an itch to climb the mountain. being on the 4 is like having unfinished business,

      so it's automatic dramatic tension for the rest of the hook to resolve. even in something like a |6m|4|1|5|, i feel like the 6m is forlorn and the 4 is what injects hope into it (noticing the top of the mountain).

the downside is i feel it's making my ideas sound too similar. like i'm making different versions of the same song each time. i would still like to make something you can dance and sing along to, and still have that dramatic tension , but what is another good way to do it without starting on the 4? do i just need to wait for my taste in melodies to change?
